subject: Re: QS news update
msgSnippet: ... This raises a very good point. I (Californian) personally sound D for T in shutter yet it is natural for me to use Tea correctly in these cases. Indeed
messageBody:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "Ted Larson Freeman"
<freeman@...> wrote:
>
> I would argue that the mental representations of words such as
> 'shudder' and 'shutter' are distinct for nearly all Americans (and
> thus the kidding that Wells refers to). I'm no linguist, but I'd offer
> the theory that a phonological transformation occurs when we (these
> Americans) convert the mental representation of 'shutter' into a
> stream of sounds, and that this transformation occurs naturally and
> without conscious effort.
>
> I think the best thing to do is to continue to represent these words
> using 'Tea' and 'Day'.
>
> Ted
>

This raises a very good point. I (Californian) personally sound D for
T in "shutter" yet it is natural for me to use Tea correctly in these
cases. Indeed it would take a extra mental effort to use Day in
"shutter" and thereby accurately reflect my own noise.

It is clearly not wrong to use Tea in "shutter" and it would be silly
for someone to chastise me for using Tea to spell "shutter" because
they hear me using [d] when I myself do not notice that I am.

It is probable that changing the D to T in such cases in the CMU still
reflects a real world accent. Indeed I too believe this would be a
good thing.

Presumably, however, it is permissible to use Day in "shutter" if the
writer thinks that is the sound of the word. But does anyone do this
in practice I wonder?

If no one has ever been tempted to write Day in "shutter" then
continuing to use the CMU without fixing these D - T issues produces
an accent that nobody has. This is obviously undesirable. If piles of
QS writers (esp. in the US) use Day for "shutter" then the CMU used as
it stands does reflect a real, if minority, accent.

The "good point" is this: having used a publication that very
accurately reflects the real sound speakers make (not their mere
mental image) we got wrong-ish results.


> On Nov 16, 2007 2:29 AM, Anthony Grahn <othermale@...> wrote:
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> > "Although they will sometimes try to kid you that it isn't so, most
> > Americans completely neutralize the /t ~ d/ opposition in the
> > t-voicing environments."
> > -John Wells, 6 September 2006
> >
> > http://www.phon.ucl.ac.uk/home/wells/blog0609.htm
> >
> > Whether one chooses to represent this in the news feed is another
> > thing, its existence is undisputable.
> >
> > the CMU dictionary has:
> >
> >
> > HUMAN HH Y UW1 M AH0 N
> > but has alternative pronunciation
> >
> > HUMAN(2) Y UW1 M AH0 N
> >
> > similarly with a previously mention problem
> > JURISTS JH UH1 R IH2 S T S
> > JURISTS(2) JH UH1 R IH2 S S
> >
> > The second choice maybe inferior in the above cases.
> >
> > But the CMU also has
> > USE Y UW1 S
> > USE(2) Y UW1 Z
> > In this case the second choice is better because the word "use" is
> > more frequent as a verb. I think.
> >
> > Carnigie Mellon's web interface to their dictionary always uses the
> > first listing.
> >
> > http://www.speech.cs.cmu.edu/cgi-bin/cmudict
> > But the alternatives pronunciations are not numbered in any sensible
> > order sometimes indicating parts of speech, sometimes indicating one
> > accent, sometimes another.
> >
> >
> > >2. Quickscript manual abbreviations
> > >Should we implement QS manual abbreviations, such as #21iNG (instead
> > >of -#26It-#21iNG) for the gerund-participle suffix "ing"? Do you
> > >want to do these one-by-one, or leave them for you to do a global
> > >update at some point?
> >
> > The hundred or so abbreviations and fixed spellings listed for
> > particular words in the senior section of the QM account for a huge
> > percent of words on a page and are a huge asset.
> >
> > For grammatical endings, it is reasonable to do morphemic endings
> > programmatically with a trivial algorithm by querying the data
for the
> > entry with the ending and then again without, if both entries exist
> > the difference is probably a suffix.
> > eg: is the -ing in "jumping" a suffix? it is if you can find
"jump" in
> > the cmu.
> > eg: is the -ing in "thing" a suffix? it is not because there is no
> > entry for "th"
> >
> >
> >
>
